G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Plaintiff, Jordan Carter, brings this action against Defendant, Susan Blake, for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as set forth in G.L. c. 186, § 14 and under common law principles.

G.L. c. 214, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 214, § 3.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant’s failure to take action despite repeated notice of the conditions demonstrates willful or knowing disregard for Plaintiff’s statutory and common law rights, thereby entitling Plaintiff to remedies under the statute.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that Gem’s repeated failure to take permanent corrective action despite ongoing complaints and notice of unsanitary flooding could be found reckless and an “outrageous omission to act,” and that such reckless interference with quiet enjoyment is actionable under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion explains that malicious intent is not required and that at least reckless, willful disregard of the tenant’s rights, shown by a long course of indifference after notice, suffices to trigger statutory remedies, including damages and attorneys’ fees.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Solomon testified that she had repeatedly complained to Gem of floods. She stated that Gem on each occasion sent a cleanup crew to pump out the water, but never took permanent action. The jury, if they believed this testimony, could find that Gem knew or should have known that unless it fixed the porous wall flooding would occur… The jury could also find that Gem had displayed, over a long and repetitious course, such a pattern of indifference that its conduct was outrageous… In sum, it could be found that Gem violated its duty to Solomon recklessly, by outrageous omission to act….”

Lindsey v. Normet, 405 U.S. 56, 74-75 (1.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease in Massachusetts includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment that protects tenants from substantial interference with their tenancy by landlords or their agents.
Lindsey v. Normet, 405 U.S. 56, 74-75 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lindsey v. Normet concerns the constitutionality of Oregon’s forcible entry and detainer (eviction) procedures under the Fourteenth Amendment. It does not interpret Massachusetts law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or discuss an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential leases. The case is about due process and equal protection in summary eviction, not about state-law implied covenants protecting tenants from landlord interference, so it does not support the specific Massachusetts landlord-tenant proposition cited.
Lindsey v. Normet, 405 U.S. 56, 74-75 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The Constitution has not federalized the substantive law of landlord-tenant relations, however, and we see nothing to forbid Oregon from treating the undertakings of the tenant and those of the landlord as independent rather than dependent covenants. ... The substantive law of landlord-tenant relations differs widely in the various States. In some jurisdictions, a tenant may argue as a defense to eviction for nonpayment of rent such claims as unrepaired building code violations, breach of an implied warranty of habitability, or the fact that the landlord is evicting him for reporting building code violations or for exercising constitutional rights."

Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355.case_name: Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Savings Bank
Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank concerns whether violation of a building code provision can constitute evidence of negligence relating to the bank’s control over building conditions. It does not address the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, substantial interference with use and enjoyment, or water intrusion/rental habitability issues. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the stated quiet enjoyment proposition and is being cited for a different legal concept (evidence of negligence from code violation).
Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the result of part 1 of the opinion on the ground that (subject to proof of other elements of liability, see Wainwright v. Jackson, 291 Mass. 100, 102-103) violation of § 1008 (a) of the Boston Building Code may be found to be evidence of negligence; i.e. failure to “exercise reasonable care to keep” a portion of the building (not a common area and not part of the premises let to the plaintiff) “in such condition that others will not be injured.”

Clark v. Leisure Woods Estates, Inc., 89.proposition: Defendant’s attempt to terminate or non-renew Plaintiff’s lease in apparent retaliation for Plaintiff exercising their right to report code violations constitutes further interference with Plaintiff’s tenancy and is prohibited under Massachusetts law.
Clark v. Leisure Woods Estates, Inc., 89.case_name: Clark v. Leisure Woods Estates, Inc.
Clark v. Leisure Woods Estates, Inc., 89.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, warranty of habitability, and G.L. c. 93A in a manufactured housing community, but it does not address retaliatory termination or non‑renewal of a lease after tenants report code violations. There is no discussion of retaliation doctrine, non‑renewal as interference, or Massachusetts anti‑retaliation protections such as G.L. c. 186, §§ 18 or 14 in a retaliatory context. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about retaliatory termination or non‑renewal of a lease.
Clark v. Leisure Woods Estates, Inc., 89.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14, however, allows tenants to recover ‘actual and consequential damages’… This provision ‘was intended to expand the damages recoverable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment,’ allowing tenants to be compensated for ‘all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery.’ … Accordingly, the plaintiffs were entitled to recover for all such losses attributable to the defendant’s interference with their use of the walking trails and its failure to repair the decaying infrastructure of their housing sites.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 851 (.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the water intrusion problem, which caused property damage, increased utility expenses, and created an untenable rental environment, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff's use and enjoyment of the premises, in violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 851 (.support_reasoning: The case does not involve water intrusion, but it does articulate the general rule for violations of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment: a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects that interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment can constitute a § 14 violation. The court cites prior cases, including ones involving leaks and habitability defects, as examples of substantial interferences. Thus, while factually different, the opinion supports the legal proposition that a landlord’s failure to remedy a serious condition that makes the premises untenable can breach quiet enjoyment, provided there is notice and negligent non‑repair.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 851 (.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 910 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take action despite repeated notice of the conditions demonstrates willful or knowing disregard for Plaintiff’s statutory and common law rights, thereby entitling Plaintiff to remedies under the statute.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The case does not support the claimed proposition about a defendant’s *willful or knowing* disregard based on repeated notice. On the rent control issue, the court explicitly upholds the trial judge’s finding that the landlord’s violation was *not* willful. On the security deposit and other statutory claims, the opinion focuses on strict statutory consequences (treble damages after demand and failure to return) rather than on a factual finding that the landlord acted with willful or knowing disregard of the tenant’s rights after repeated notice.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s finding that Young’s violation was not wilful is not clearly erroneous, as Young could easily have had the property decontrolled much earlier. The tenant is, however, entitled to attorney’s fees and costs under the ordinance, as § 9 expressly provides for liability for reasonable attorney’s fees and costs for any person who ‘receives, or retains any payment of rent, in excess of the maximum lawful rent.’ A showing that a violation is neither wilful nor the result of failure to take practicable precautions merely limits the amount of liquidated damages to the amount of the overcharge.”

Berman & Sons v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 19.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the water intrusion problem, which caused property damage, increased utility expenses, and created an untenable rental environment, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff's use and enjoyment of the premises, in violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 19.support_reasoning: The case concerns breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement for loss of heat and hot water, not the covenant of quiet enjoyment or water intrusion causing property damage or increased utilities. The court’s analysis is framed entirely in terms of habitability standards and economic rent abatement, not substantial interference with use and enjoyment under the quiet enjoyment covenant. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Berman & Sons v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 19.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition…”
